document.masterDocTitle: A review of the genus Trachelas (Araneae: Corinnidae) from China

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 1. Leg measurements of
Trachelas acuminus (Zhu & An, 1988)
, male.

FIGURES 1–10.
Trachelas acuminus (Zhu et An, 1988)
. 1. Male body, dorsal view. 2. Endites, labium and sternum of male, ventral view. 3. Left chelicera of male, posterior view. 4. Carapace and chelicerae of male, front view. 5. Tibia, metatarsus and tarsus of male right leg I, showing cusps. 6. Left male palp, prolateral view. 7. Same, ventral view. 8. Same, retrolateral view. 9. Epigynum, ventral view. 10. Vulva, dorsal view. Scale bars: 1 mm (1, 5); 0.3 mm (3, 9–10); 0.4 mm (6–8); 0.5 mm (2, 4).

TABLE 2. Leg measurements of
Trachelas acuminus (Zhu et An, 1988)
, female.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Femur Patella Tibia Metatarsus Tarsus Total I 1.26 0.40 1.19 0.87 0.56 4.29 II 1.05 0.45 0.95 0.75 0.45 3.65 III 0.87 0.40 1.03 0.56 0.40 3.25 IV 1.11 0.48 0.95 0.87 0.48 3.89 Epigynum as in
Figs. 9–10
. Epigynal plate weakly sclerotized, with anterior hood, slightly M-shaped; two copulatory openings concave, located posteromedially near the epigastric furrow. Bursa situated lateral of copulatory openings, short, club-shaped; spermathecae elongate oval, larger and longer than bursa, situated medially, connecting with the copulatory ducts through a thin duct; fertilization ducts short, arising from the posterolateral ends of the spermathecae.

Type material.
Clubiona acumina Zhu et An, 1988
: the type specimens were deposited in the Museum of Hebei University, examined.
Trachelas coreanus
Paik, 1991
: the original specimens were presumably lost (according to
Kim and Lee, 2008
), not examined.

Material examined. CHINA : Shanxi Province, Yicheng County (
N 25.34 °
,
E 100.13 °
), female holotype , male ‘allotype’, 132 Ƥ paratypes ( MHBU ),
17 July 1983
, M. S. Zhu leg.

Remarks.
Trachelas acuminus (
Zhu & An, 1988
)
seems to be a special species as it differs from other
Trachelas
species distributed in China . However, based on the functional conductor and embolus shape, the ventral cusps in males, and arrangement of the spermathecae, it is similar to
T. maculatus
and
T. validus
distributed in the Europe, and belongs to the Eurasian
T. validus
species group (
Bosselaers et al., 2009
).
